items.content:
In this chapter we will have a look at the circulatory system. You will need the handout of chapter 3 for this. The exercises will be made on your tablets. Make sure to bring them (loaded). Also make sure you bring a notebook to write in and a pen, pencil, eraser and protractor triangle in case will make a drawing.

We will do these paragraphs:

3.1: A matter of the heart

3.2: What goes around comes around

3.3: Highways and byways

3.4: Blood pressure and heart disease

3.5: The parts of blood

Read the text of paragraph 3.1 and then complete the following questions.

1. What type of muscle tissue is the heart made of?
A. Voluntary muscle
B. Involuntary muscle
C. Cardiac muscle

2. Which heart chambers contain blood low in oxygen?

3. Which heart chambers contain blood rich in oxygen?

4. Which heart chamber does oxygen-poor blood enter first?

5. Which heart chamber does oxygen-rich blood enter first?

6. When the atria contract, blood flows
A. To the aorta and the lungs
B. To the ventricles
C. To the other organs
D. To the septum

7. When the ventricles contract, blood flows
A. To the aorta and the lungs
B. To the atria
C. To the other organs
D. To the septum
Complete the three exercises below.

content.body:
1. Put the phrases in the correct order to make sentences.

  • The pumping of your heart .
  • Materials .
  • This keeps .
  • The wall .
through your body
by the circulatory system
contractions and relaxations
are moved
all your life
is more muscular
than the right ventricle
of cardiac muscle tissue
around your body
is caused by
the blood flowing
the regular and repetitive
of the left ventricle

2. The four valves in figure 3.2 in your handout do not all open and close at the same time. When the valves between the atria and the ventricles are open, the valves between the ventricles and their connecting blood vessels are closed and vice versa.
For both situations mentioned, write the words 'open' and 'closed' in the appropriate place.

  • When the artria contract, the aortic valve is , the bicuspid valve is , the pulmonary valve is and the tricuspid valve is .
  • When the ventricles contract, the aortic valve is , the bicuspid valve is , the pulmonary valve is and the tricuspid valve is .

prompt.body: 3. Study figure 3.1 in your handout. Below you will find statements that represent the stages of blood flow through the heart. Put them in the right order.

content.body: Both ventricles contract and oxygen-rich blood leaves the heart through the aorta.
Both ventricles contract and oxygen-poor blood leaves the right ventricle through a blood vessel, towards the lungs.
START HERE: Oxygen-rich blood enters the heart and fills the left atrium.
Oxygen-poor blood enters the lungs, releases excess carbon dioxide and picks up oxygen to be-come oxygen-rich blood.
Oxygen-poor blood enters the heart from the other organs, through two blood vessels.
Both atria contract and oxygen-poor blood goes down to fill the right ventricle.
Oxygen-rich blood travels back to the heart from the lungs through two pairs of blood vessels.
Both atria contract and oxygen-rich blood travels down to fill the left ventricle.
Oxygen-poor blood fills the right atrium.

items.content:
Go to the Kid's Health website - ASD and look at het pictures and read the texts about atrial septal defect (ASD) in the box (slide 1 to 6, see the figure on the right).

The parts of the heart can be abbreviated to:
AO = aorta RA = right atrium
LA = left atrium PA = pulmonary artery
LV = left ventricle RV = right ventricle

1. The atria contract. Write down the letters of the correct statement(s):
a. Oxygen-poor blood will flow from RA into RV.
b. Oxygen-poor blood will flow from RA into LA.
c. Oxygen-poor blood will be present in RV.
d. Mixed blood will flow from RA into RV.
e. Oxygen-rich blood will flow from LA into RA.
f. Oxygen-rich blood will flow from RA into LA.
g. Mixed blood will be present in RV.

Now go to the Kid's Health website - VSD and look at het pictures and read the texts about ventricular septal defect (VSD) in the box (slide 1 to 6).

2. The left ventricle pumps blood with a greater force than the right ventricle. In which direction do you think blood will flow through the hole in the septum?

3. What consequences might this have for the patient?

You are going to measure your heart rate.

Method
• Put your fingers on your wrist as can be seen in the figure on the right.
• Count the number of heartbeats for a minute (or 30 seconds and multiply by 2).
• Now stand up and make 20 squats beside your chair and table.
• Again count the number of heartbeats for a minute (or 30 seconds and multiply by 2).

Results
a. What is your resting heart rate?
b. What is your heart rate after exercise?

c. Now look at the graph below. You can see the connection between heart rate and type of activity. Explain why the line representing the heart rate goes up. Use the words: energy - oxygen - respiration.

Do these exercises for practice:

A: Label the heart

B: Label the heart as fast as possible

C: Label the heart by writing the words

D: Label the heart interactive (with live feedback!)

Keep repeating the exercises until you know all the parts!

Write the following in your notebook:

Tasks

a. Explain what you did in the exercises (f.e. exercise 1: answering questions about the heart)

b. Add a + when you managed well or a - when you could have done it better

Learning objectives

c. Write down at least 3 things you should know from this paragraph

d. Add a + when you know these learning objectives or a - when you do not know them yet
Read the text of paragraph 3.2 and then complete the following exercise.

content.body:
Identify the following items as having oxygenated or deoxygenated blood:

  • The aorta has oxygenated / deoxygenated blood.
  • The coronary arteries have oxygenated / deoxygenated blood.
  • The coronary veins have oxygenated / deoxygenated blood.
  • The pulmonary arteries have oxygenated / deoxygenated blood.
  • The pulmonary veins have oxygenated / deoxygenated blood.
  • The inferior vena cava has oxygenated / deoxygenated blood.
  • The superior vena cava has oxygenated / deoxygenated blood.
  • The left atrium has oxygenated / deoxygenated blood.
  • The right atrium has oxygenated / deoxygenated blood.
  • The left ventricle has oxygenated / deoxygenated blood.
  • The right ventricle has oxygenated / deoxygenated blood.

items.content:
Answer the following questions.

1. When blood leaves the heart, through which blood vessels does it leave?

2. When blood enters the heart, through which blood vessels does it enter?

3. Which section of the circulatory system is shown in the picture on the right?
A. Part of the coronary circulation
B. Part of the pulmonary circulation
C. Part of the systemic circulation

4. Blood makes up 8% of your body's total mass. Calculate how many kilograms of blood travel through your body. Show your calculations.

5. In the pulmonary circulation, which ventricle pumps blood towards the lungs and along which blood vessel?

6. In the systemic circulation, which ventricle pumps blood towards the rest of the organs and along which blood vessel?

7. Look again at your answers to questions 5 and 6. Why do you think the human circulatory system is often called a double circulation and the human heart a 'double pump'?

content.body:
In one of your organs blood is clotting together forming a blood clot. This blood clot is small enough to travel through your blood vessels. What route will it take when returning to this or another organ?

  • The route of the blood clot is: organ > > > > > > > > > > organ.
right atrium
left atrium
pulmonary vein
right ventricle
pulmonary artery
left ventricle
lungs
superior/inferior cava
aorta

items.content:
Write the following in your notebook:

Tasks

a. Explain what you did in the exercises (f.e. exercise 1: answering questions about the heart)

b. Add a + when you managed well or a - when you could have done it better

Learning objectives

c. Write down at least 3 things you should know from this paragraph

d. Add a + when you know these learning objectives or a - when you do not know them yet

Read the text of paragraph 3.3 and then have a look at the construction of the blood vessels.

After that complete the following exercise.

content.body:
Below are several statements about blood vessels. Identify each statement as belonging to most arteries, to most veins or to capillaries.

  • Muscular: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Away from the heart to the organs: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Oxygenated blood: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Elastic walls: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • High pressure: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Small diameter: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Valves: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Less muscular: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Wide diameter: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Very low pressure: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Away from organs towards heart: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Deoxygenated blood: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Microscopic: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Not muscular: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Lower pressure: most arteries / most veins / capillaries
  • Diameter 0.001 mm: most arteries / most veins / capillaries

items.content:
Answer the following questions (1 to 8).

1. Deborah says that all arteries contain oxygenated blood. Is she correct?
Explain your answer.

2. Onno says that all veins contain oxygenated blood. Is he correct?
Explain your answer.

3. Where does the exchange of oxygen, nutrients and waste substances occur?
A. In the arteries
B. In the veins
C. In the capillaries
D. In the heart

4. The picture on the top is an electron microscope image, showing a section through a blood vessel. The cells surrounding the blood vessel are pancreatic cells. Using the images, what type of blood vessel do you think is shown in the picture?
Explain your answer.

The amount of blood that flows to various organs is different when you are at rest to when you are exercising (see the figure on the right).

5. Which organs get the biggest increase in their share of the blood supply during physical exertion?
Include a calculation with your answer.

6. Which organs get the biggest decrease in their share of the blood supply during physical exertion?
Include a calculation with your answer.

7. The hepatic artery and the portal vein both transport blood to the liver (look online where to locate these blood vessels). The blood in the portal vein contains less oxygen than the blood in the hepatic artery.
Explain why.

8. The composition of the blood in the portal vein can vary considerably. This blood can contain a lot more nutrients at certain times.
Explain why.

Answer the following questions.
The figure below shows a schematic drawing of the circulatory system of a frog.

1. What compartments are there in the heart of a frog?

Breathing in frogs occurs both through the lungs and the skin. The blood that has been enriched with oxygen in these organs flows back to the heart (see the figure).

2. Which parts of the heart does this oxygenated blood reach first?
- The oxygenated blood from the lungs first reaches ......................
- The oxygenated blood from the skin first reaches ........................

3. In humans, the right atrium contains deoxygenated blood.
Does the blood in the right atrium of a frog contain more or less oxygen than the blood in the right atrium of a human? Explain your answer.

You can use the following method to see your own blood flow. Answer the questions below.

Drawing 1: Make your left hand into a fist. You will see blood vessels on the back of your hand. Press one of those blood vessels closed with the middle finger of your right hand.
Drawing 2: Use the index finger of your right hand to push the blood in the closed blood vessel away in the direction of your wrist.
Drawing 3: If you keep the blood vessel closed with your middle finger, no more new blood will flow into this blood vessel because the valves stop the blood from flowing back.
Drawing 4: When you stop pressing on the blood vessel, the blood will flow back into the blood vessel.

1. Follow the instructions in the text above. Are the blood vessels in the drawings veins or arteries? Explain your answer.

2. Does the blood in the blood vessels flow from left to right or from right to left?

There are valves at positions P, Q and R in drawing 3.

3. Which of these valves will stop the blood from flowing back in this situation? Explain your answer.

Write the following in your notebook:

Tasks

a. Explain what you did in the exercises (f.e. exercise 1: answering questions about the heart)

b. Add a + when you managed well or a - when you could have done it better

Learning objectives

c. Write down at least 3 things you should know from this paragraph

d. Add a + when you know these learning objectives or a - when you do not know them yet

Read the text of paragraph 3.4 and then complete the following questions.

1. Blood pressure is highest in the arteries and lowest in the veins. Explain why this is so.

2. Why do you think arteries are found deeper inside your body than veins?

3. Explain why your pulse is usually taken at your arm or neck even though arteries are found throughout your body.

4. Which of the two diagrams below represents systole and which represents diastole? Give the correct name for each picture.

5. Hypertension and atherosclerosis are examples of a group of diseases called cardiovascular diseases (which means diseases of the heart ('cardio') and blood vessels ('vascular')).
The X-ray photo on the right was made after a contrast liquid was injected into the coronary arteries of a patient with heart problems. The doctor marked a spot on the photo with an arrow. What do you think this patient is suffering from?
Explain your answer.

The diagram of the heart below shows three places (A, B and C) where blood vessels supplying blood to the heart could become blocked causing a heart attack.

6. What do we call a blood vessel that supplies blood to the heart muscle?

7. What is the blockage of such a blood vessel called?

8. What do we call a blood vessel that takes blood away from the heart muscle?

9. Which part (A, B or C) would cause the most serious heart attack?
Give reasons for your answer.

Read the following article and answer the questions.

Brush teeth to 'prevent' heart disease
28 May 2010

People who fail to brush their teeth twice a day are putting themselves at risk of heart disease, research suggests.

The Scottish study of more than 11,000 adults backs previous research linking gum disease with heart problems. The researchers said more work is needed to confirm if poor oral health directly causes heart disease or just points to a higher risk. They added that oral hygiene was just one factor in good heart health.

It is known that inflammation in the body, including in the mouth and gums, has an important role in the build up of clogged arteries, which can lead to a heart attack. But this is the first time that researchers have looked at whether the frequency of teeth brushing has any bearing on the risk of developing heart disease.

Data, published in the British Medical Journal was collected on lifestyle behaviours, such as smoking, physical activity and oral health routines. Participants were also asked how often they visited the dentist and how often they brushed their teeth. Then nurses collected information on age, medical history and family history of heart disease, took blood pressure and blood samples.

Overall, six out of 10 people said they visited the dentist every six months and seven out 10 reported brushing their teeth twice a day. Over the eightyear study there were 555 'cardiovascular events' such as heart attacks, 170 of which were fatal.

Taking into account factors that affect heart disease risk, such as obesity, smoking and family history, the researchers found those with the worst oral hygiene had a 70% increased chance of developing the condition compared with those who brush their teeth twice a day.

Judy O'Sullivan, senior cardiac nurse at British Heart Foundation, said: "If you don't brush your teeth, your mouth can become infected with bacteria which can cause inflammation." However, it is complicated by the fact that poor oral hygiene is often associated with other well known risk factors for heart disease. One such factor is smoking, which increases blood pressure and makes the inside walls of arteries rough. This causes fatty deposits to form easily. Another risk factor is poor diet." She added: "Good personal hygiene is a basic element of a healthy lifestyle." But if you want to help your heart, you should eat a balanced diet, avoid smoking and take part in regular physical activity."

Professor Damien Walmsley, scientific adviser to the British Dental Association, added it was still unclear whether there was a definite cause and effect between oral hygiene and heart disease. "Whatever the true position is, we can say with certainty that if people brush teeth twice a day with fluoride toothpaste, visit the dentist regularly
and restrict sugary snacks to mealtimes; that this will go a long way towards keeping the teeth and gums in a healthy state for life."

Source: BBC News

1. How can 'clogged arteries' (paragraph 3) lead to a heart attack?

2. Why did the nurses in the study ask the participants about their age (paragraph 4)?

3. The nurses also measured the participants' blood pressure (paragraph 4).
What is the connection between blood pressure and heart attacks?

4. Of the participants that suffered from a cardiovascular problem during the study, how many survived?

5. According to the text, one factor that affects heart disease is family history (paragraph 6). What do they mean by this?

6. How can smoking cause heart disease?

7. How can 'poor diet' (paragraph 7) lead to a heart attack?

8. What is a direct result if you do not brush your teeth?

9. According to the text, what things can you do to prevent heart disease?

Write the following in your notebook:

Tasks

a. Explain what you did in the exercises (f.e. exercise 1: answering questions about the heart)

b. Add a + when you managed well or a - when you could have done it better

Learning objectives

c. Write down at least 3 things you should know from this paragraph

d. Add a + when you know these learning objectives or a - when you do not know them yet

Read the text of paragraph 3.4 and then complete the following questions.

1. Write down five components of plasma.

2. In a test tube, which is heavier: the layer of white blood cells or the layer of red blood cells? Give a reason for your answer.

3. In a test tube, which is heavier: the layer of white blood cells or the layer of red platelets? Give a reason for your answer.

4. Complete the following concept map about the parts of blood:

5. Red blood cells are made at a rate of 2 million per second in the centre of long bones. How many millions of red blood cells are made in one hour? Show your calculations.

Read the text about Jasper and answer questions 6 to 10.

Jasper is taking part in a scientific experiment about exercise and the effects on the human body. He undergoes several activities (1 - 5). The results of the experiment are shown in the table below. Study the data in the table and answer the questions.

6. Which substances does your blood transport towards your tissues?

7. Which substances does your blood transport away from your tissues?

8. Here is a list of 5 activities: walking slowly, sprinting, sleeping, sitting down, marching. Decide which activity belongs to which number in the table above. Write down the correct combinations in your notebook.

9. Explain why Jasper's heart rate must go up from activity 1 to activity 5.

10. Jasper's temperature goes up with each activity. Explain why he needs to sweat more from activity 1 to activity 5.

Read the text about Johanneke and answer question 11 to 14.

Johanneke suffers from anaemia: a condition which causes her to get tired and weak very quickly. Sometimes she looks very pale and now and then she gets short of breath. Her doctor tested her blood. He told Johanneke that her blood cannot transport oxygen as well as it should. She has a 'low blood cell count'.

11. What type of blood cells is her doctor talking about? Explain your reasoning.

12. What substance in your blood is responsible for binding and transporting oxygen in blood cells?

13. Why does anaemia cause people to get tired and weak?

14. Anaemia is more common is women than in men. Can you think of a biological reason for this?

Write the following in your notebook:

Tasks

a. Explain what you did in the exercises (f.e. exercise 1: answering questions about the heart)

b. Add a + when you managed well or a - when you could have done it better

Learning objectives

c. Write down at least 3 things you should know from this paragraph

d. Add a + when you know these learning objectives or a - when you do not know them yet

1. Heart and Circulation animation by e-learning for kids. It also has an exercise for practice.

2. Animations about Blood Circulation. You can find extra information about 'construction of the blood vessels', 'blood cells and blood plasma' and 'construction and operation of the heart'.

values.value:
1. C
2. The right atrium and right ventricle.
3. The left atrium and the left ventricle.
4. The right atrium.

5. The left atrium.

6. B
7. A

content.body:
1. C
2. The right atrium and right ventricle.
3. The left atrium and the left ventricle.
4. The right atrium.

5. The left atrium.

6. B
7. A

values.value:
1. b-d-e-g.
2. From the LV to the RV.
3. Not all oxygen rich blood goes through the aorta to the rest of the body. The patient may tire faster.

content.body:
1. b-d-e-g.
2. From the LV to the RV.
3. Not all oxygen rich blood goes through the aorta to the rest of the body. The patient may tire faster.

values.value:
a. Own answer

b. Own answer

c. The more you exercise the more energy you need. More energy means more oxygen. In order to keep respiration up the heart must circulate more oxygen faster so the heart rate goes up.

content.body:
a. Own answer

b. Own answer

c. The more you exercise the more energy you need. More energy means more oxygen. In order to keep respiration up the heart must circulate more oxygen faster so the heart rate goes up.

values.value:
1. Through the aorta and the pulmonary arteries.

2. Inferior and superior vena cava and the pulmonary veins.

3. A.

4. Answer varies per student. Example: 50 kg x 0.08 = 4 kg of blood.

5. Right ventricle along the pulmonary arteries.

6. Left ventricle along the aorta.

7. Because the blood travels through the heart twice to pass through the entire body.

content.body:
1. Through the aorta and the pulmonary arteries.

2. Inferior and superior vena cava and the pulmonary veins.

3. A.

4. Answer varies per student. Example: 50 kg x 0.08 = 4 kg of blood.

5. Right ventricle along the pulmonary arteries.

6. Left ventricle along the aorta.

7. Because the blood travels through the heart twice to pass through the entire body.

values.value:
1. No, the pulmonary arteries do not contain oxygenated blood.
2. No, only the pulmonary veins contain oxygenated blood.
3. C.
4. Capillaries, it has a very thin wall and only one red blood cell can fit in the diameter.
5. The muscles. The share rises from 20% to 78%: an increase of 58%.
6. The digestive organs. The share falls from 30% to 5%: a decrease of 25%.
(None of the other organs have a decrease of 25% or more.)
7. The blood in the por tal vein comes from the intestinal tract. The intestinal tract has used the oxygen for respiration.
8. This is related to the absorption of nutrients from the small intestine.

content.body:
1. No, the pulmonary arteries do not contain oxygenated blood.
2. No, only the pulmonary veins contain oxygenated blood.
3. C.
4. Capillaries, it has a very thin wall and only one red blood cell can fit in the diameter.
5. The muscles. The share rises from 20% to 78%: an increase of 58%.
6. The digestive organs. The share falls from 30% to 5%: a decrease of 25%.
(None of the other organs have a decrease of 25% or more.)
7. The blood in the por tal vein comes from the intestinal tract. The intestinal tract has used the oxygen for respiration.
8. This is related to the absorption of nutrients from the small intestine.

values.value:
1. Two atria and one ventricle.
2. – The oxygenated blood from the lungs first reaches the left atrium.
    – The oxygenated blood from the skin first reaches the right atrium.
3. More oxygen, because in frogs the deoxygenated blood coming from the organs is first mixed with the oxygenated blood from the skin. Then the mixed blood flows into the right atrium.

content.body:
1. Two atria and one ventricle.
2. - The oxygenated blood from the lungs first reaches the left atrium.
- The oxygenated blood from the skin first reaches the right atrium.
3. More oxygen, because in frogs the deoxygenated blood coming from the organs is first mixed with the oxygenated blood from the skin. Then the mixed blood flows into the right atrium.

values.value:
1. The closest to the heart the pressure is the highest. The further away, the lower the pressure.

2. Because of the higher pressure inside arteries, you would lose more blood if a arteries would be damaged.

3. At those spots the arteries run relatively close to the surface of your body.

4. A = diastole    B = systole

5. A fatty deposit in a coronary artery. You can see that less blood flows after the arrow.

6. Coronary artery.

7. A plaque.

8. Coronary vein.

9. A: It shuts down the complete heart. It is closest to the aorta.

content.body:
1. The closest to the heart the pressure is the highest. The further away, the lower the pressure.

2. Because of the higher pressure inside arteries, you would lose more blood if a arteries would be damaged.

3. At those spots the arteries run relatively close to the surface of your body.

4. A = diastole B = systole

5. A fatty deposit in a coronary artery. You can see that less blood flows after the arrow.

6. Coronary artery.

7. A plaque.

8. Coronary vein.

9. A: It shuts down the complete heart. It is closest to the aorta.

values.value:
1. The heart will receive less blood because less blood flows back out of the body.

2. Because older people could get a heart attack more often than younger people.

3. The higher a blood pressure, the higher the risk of a heart attack. The diastole must not be too high.

4. 555 – 170 = 385 patients survived.

5. Inheritance. If heart attacks run in the family the chance is great that the patients run a higher risk.

6. Due to smoking the arteries get narrower, increasing the blood pressure. (It makes the artery walls rough.)

7. Poor diet more often contains more fat. This fat can bedeposited on the walls of blood vessels, causing plaque.

8. You suffer inflammation of the gums and tooth decay.

9. Quote: ” But if you want to help your heart, you should eat a balanced diet, avoid smoking and take part in regular physical activity.”

content.body:
1. The heart will receive less blood because less blood flows back out of the body.

2. Because older people could get a heart attack more often than younger people.

3. The higher a blood pressure, the higher the risk of a heart attack. The diastole must not be too high.

4. 555 - 170 = 385 patients survived.

5. Inheritance. If heart attacks run in the family the chance is great that the patients run a higher risk.

6. Due to smoking the arteries get narrower, increasing the blood pressure. (It makes the artery walls rough.)

7. Poor diet more often contains more fat. This fat can bedeposited on the walls of blood vessels, causing plaque.

8. You suffer inflammation of the gums and tooth decay.

9. Quote: " But if you want to help your heart, you should eat a balanced diet, avoid smoking and take part in regular physical activity."
